questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements about the reticular activating system is false?

options.d: Does not produce EEG alerting response

questions.explanation:
High-frequency stimulation of the midbrain reticular formation (the RAS) produces the EEG 
alerting response and arouses a sleeping animal. The Reticular Activating System (RAS) is a complex polysynaptic pathway arising from the 
brainstem reticular formation and hypothalamus with projections to the intralaminar and 
reticular nuclei of the thalamus which, in turn, project diffusely and nonspecifically to wide 
regions of the cortex including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital cortices. Collaterals funnel into it from the long ascending sensory tracts, the trigeminal, auditory, visual, 
and olfactory systems. 338 
Sold by @itachibot The reticular formation plays an important role in determining the level of arousal; thus, it is 
called the ascending reticular activating system (ARAS).

questions.question: Question 2: Which is the EEG wave recorded in a subject who is awake but eyes closed?
questions.explanation:
Alpha-waves are recorded best in the parieto-occipital region in adults at rest, i.e. awake but 
relaxed with eyes closed.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following structures regulates the sleep-wake cycle?
questions.explanation:
The hypothalamus and several non-specific nuclei in ascending reticular activating system (ARAS) 
located in the midbrain are involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle. Sleep Centres Stimulation of the midbrain reticular formation (RAS) produces the EEG alerting response and 
promotes the waking state. The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the raphe nuclei of ARAS is 
rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce wakefulness. The cholinergic neurons in the pontine reticular formation, on stimulation, induce sleep. Stimulation of the histaminergic neurons of the posterior hypothalamus produces arousal. Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region 
rapidly induces sleep. This sleep-inducing effect is thought to be mediated by GABA-ergic 
inhibitory neurons. Orexin produced by hypothalamic neurons also appears to have a role in sleep-wake transition by 
regulating the changes in activity in these brainstem neurons. Sleep wakeful stat 
e Acetylcholi 
ne Norepinephr 
ine Serotonin 
GABA Histamine

questions.question: Question 4: In which stage of sleep are K complex and sleep spindles seen?
questions.explanation:
Stage 2 of NREM sleep is marked by the appearance of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles 
(12–14 Hz) and occasional high-voltage biphasic waves called K complexes. 339 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which stage constitutes the largest amount of sleep time of a young adult?
questions.explanation:
• In young adults, the largest amount of sleep time (50–60%) is spent in stage 2 NREM sleep; 
REM phases constitute 20–25% of total sleep time, stages 3 and 4 NREM about 15–20%, and 
stage 1 non-REM about 5%. • REM sleep occupies 80% of total sleep time in premature infants and 50 % in full-term 
neonates. In most adults, it is 25 %. In the elderly, it falls to about 20%.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is observed during sleep induction?
questions.explanation:
The cholinergic neurons in pontine reticular formation on stimulation, induce sleep. When the activity of norepinephrine and serotonin containing neurons (locus coeruleus and raphe 
nuclei) is dominant, there is a reduced level of activity in acetylcholine-containing neurons in the 
pontine reticular formation leading to wakefulness. The reverse of this pattern leads to REM 
sleep. A more even balance in the activity of these groups of neurons is associated with NREM 
sleep.

questions.question: Question 7: In NREM sleep, which part of brain is not involved?
questions.explanation:
The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the Raphe nuclei of ARAS is 
rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce arousal. Thus, the dorsal raphe nucleus is 
not involved in NREM sleep. Genesis and Regulation of NREM sleep 340 
Sold by @itachibot • Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region 
rapidly induces sleep mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons called the NREM-on cells. • These cells are thought to produce sleep by inhibiting the histaminergic cells in the posterior 
hypothalamus as well as cells of the nucleus reticularis pontis oralis in the midbrain that mediate 
arousal. • They are maximally active in NREM sleep and inactive during waking and REM sleep. • NREM sleep is produced by synchronized synaptic potentials in cortical neurons generated by 
the rhythmic firing of thalamic relay neurons that project to the cortex. (Thalamocortical loop)

questions.question: Question 8: Delta waves are seen in
questions.explanation:
Delta waves are predominant in N3 (formerly called stage 3 and 4) of NREM. This is characteristic 
of deep sleep, also referred to as slow wave sleep. (Delta waves for Deep sleep)

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is associated with slow-wave sleep?
questions.explanation: In slow-wave sleep, (Stages 3 and 4 of NREM) delta waves predominate the EEG.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the source of melatonin?
questions.explanation:
Melatonin is released by the pineal gland (pinealocytes) that plays an important role in sleep 
mechanisms. In infants, the pineal gland is large and the cells are arranged in alveoli. It begins to involute 
before puberty and small concretions of calcium phosphate and carbonate appear (radiopaque 
structure) = physiological calcification.

questions.question:
Question 11: A businessman who takes frequent long trips to overseas destinations visits the clinic asking 
for ''something that helps with falling asleep and adapt with the local time''. He is given a low 
dose of melatonin as a part of his treatment plan. Which of the following best describes its 
action?
questions.explanation:
Melatonin plays a key role in regulating the circadian rhythm. Therefore it is helpful in restoring 
the usual sleep wake pattern in patients with jetlag. Diurnal variation in melatonin secretion may function as a timing signal to coordinate events with 
the light-dark cycle in the environment (circadian rhythm). Melatonin synthesis and secretion are increased during the dark period of the day and maintained 
at low levels during the daytime. Increased melatonin levels induce sleepiness. 341 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: In which type of memory are basal ganglia involved?
questions.explanation:
Procedural memory includes skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and 
automatic. This type of memory is processed in the striatum. Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory: It does not require being conscious or awareness. E.g., 
Remembering how to brush your teeth. They are of 4 types: • Procedural memory (skills and habits) in striatum, cerebellum, motor cortex • Priming in neocortex • Non-associative learning (includes habituation and sensitization, e.g., Byhearting facts) • Associative learning: classical and operant conditioning Explicit/declarative memory: Memory of words,rules, language, etc. Associated with 
consciousness/awareness. E.g., recalling first day in school. They are of two types: • Semantic memory (facts) e.g., Knowing capital of India: Parts of brain involved are temporal 
cortex and prefrontal cortex. • Episodic memory (events) e.g., Recalling first day in college: hippocampus, medial temporal lobe 
and neocortex.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 50-year-old lady develops severe anterograde amnesia. On further evaluation, a suprasellar 
craniopharyngioma invading adjacent structures is seen on T1-weighted MRI. Compression of 
which of the following structures can explain her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Compression or a lesion affecting the mammillary body will cause anterograde amnesia. The Hippocampus, mammillary body and mammillothalamic tract are the primary structures 
involved in the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory. Any lesion involving this 342 
Sold by @itachibot pathway will affect the ability to convert short-term memory to long-term memory, leading to 
anterograde amnesia.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following neural mechanism is not involved in synaptic plasticity and learning?
questions.explanation:
Sensitization is a neural mechanism involved in synaptic plasticity and learning (not 
desensitization). Neural basis of synaptic plasticity and learning • Post-tetanic Potentiation • Production of enhanced postsynaptic potential, which occurs after a brief tetanizing train of 
stimuli in the presynaptic neuron • This enhancement lasts up to 60 seconds. • Habituation • A simple form of learning in which neutral stimulus is repeated many times until the subject 
becomes habituated to the stimulus and ignores it • A classic example of non-associative learning (e.g., learning a fact by heart) • Sensitization: The opposite of habituation • Long-term Potentiation (LTP) • A rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to 
presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron • Characteristically observed in the hippocampus • Long-term Depression • Is the opposite of LTP • Characterized by a decrease in synaptic strength • Produced by slower stimulation of presynaptic neuron • May be involved in the neural mechanism by which learning occurs in the cerebellum

questions.question: Question 15: The type of potentiation in hippocampus is
questions.explanation:
Long-term potentiation occurs in the hippocampus. LTP is a rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to 
presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron. NMDA receptors are involved in LTP.

questions.question: Question 16: Wernickes area is in
questions.explanation:
343 
Sold by @itachibot • Wernicke’s area, lies behind the primary auditory cortex in the posterior part of the superior 
gyrus of the temporal lobe. • Wernicke’s area is concerned with language comprehension.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is false about Broca’s aphasia?
questions.explanation:
• Repetition is impaired in Broca’s aphasia. • Aphasias are abnormalities of language functions that are not due to defects of vision or hearing 
or motor paralysis. They are caused by lesions in the categorical hemispheres.

questions.question: Question 18: A lesion in the broca’s area will affect which of the following?
questions.explanation:
A lesion in broca’s area will lead to an impairment of word-formation. Broca’s area is in the inferior frontal lobe. Broca area processes the information received from the wernicke area into a detailed and 
coordinated pattern for vocalization and then projects the pattern via a speech articulation area in 
the insula to the motor cortex. This then initiates the appropriate movements of the lips, tongue, 
and larynx to produce speech. The probable sequence of events that occurs when a subject names a visual object is shown in the 
figure and flowchart. 344 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient is able to recognize a person by name but not face. Which of the following is the 
most likely site of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
This condition is prosopagnosia, which occurs in the lesions of the inferior occipitotemporal lobe. In humans, storage and recognition of faces are more strongly represented in the right inferior 
temporal lobe in right-handed individuals (i.e non-dominant inferior temporal lobe). Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia, the inability to recognize faces. Patients with this 
abnormality can recognize people by their voices, body language, etc. However, they cannot 
identify the familiar people by seeing their faces. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the role 
of the right hemisphere is primary. 345 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory?

options.a: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
options.b: Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps
options.c: Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed
options.d: Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps

questions.explanation:
Forward digit span test is the best test among the given options. Memory is of 3 types: • Immediate • Recent • Remote Immediate memory is attention dependent. Tests of attention and memory include • Digit span test: Most important and best test for immediate memory • Serial (100-7) subtraction test is the best for concentration • Days of the week backwards • Spell WORLD backwards • (20–3) test Digit span test The examiner recites numbers randomly without any sequence and asks the patient to repeat the 
same. The examiner starts with a 2-number sequence and the digit span increases from 2 
numbers to 3 numbers and so on. The patient is asked to repeat until he/she fails to repeat all 
numbers correctly. Digit forward • Normally a person can repeat up to 7 digits (+/- 2) • E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - ˜. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 
–5 –7 –˜. Digit backward • Reproduction of longer digits in backward direction. • Normally a person can repeat up to 5 digits (+/- 1) in backward direction (making option C 
wrong) • Eg : Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - ˜. The person has to repeat it backwards. ˜ -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2. Serial (100-7) subtraction test • 5 scores / steps are taken in to account • 1st score – When the patient tells ˜3 (100 - 7 = ˜3) • 2nd score - When the patient tells 86 (˜3 – 7 = 86) • And so on . . 100 , ˜3 , 86 , 7˜ , 72 , 65 Hence among the given options : Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed would be the answer of choice as it is the 
best test for immediate memory 346 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: The marked area given in the sleep polysomnography is of
questions.explanation:
The marked area in the given polysomnography represents REM sleep. The three zones in the given image represent EOG, EEG and EMG, respectively. The following table helps identify the state of wakefulness from the graph : In the marked area, • EOG shows Positive activity • EEG shows Mixed waves • EMG shows Minimal activity This is characteristic of REM sleep. EEG 
EOG 
EMG Active stat 
e Fast 
+ 
+ Mixe 
d REM slee 
p + 
- NREM sle 
ep Slow

+ 347 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: In which phase of sleep bruxism occurs?
questions.explanation:
Sleep-related bruxism is diagnosed when an individual grinds or clenches the teeth during 
sleep. Bruxism occurs more commonly during NREM 2. Parasomnias refer to abnormal behavior or experiences that arise from or occur during sleep.

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following sleep disorder does not occur in stage 3 of NREM? 335 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Bruxism occurs in stage 2 of NREM, whereas other sleep disorders given in the option occur in 
stage 3 of NREM

questions.question:
Question 24: A 30-year-old male, who met with an RTA, regained consciousness after 36 hours. It was then 
discovered that the patient is unable to create new memories. Which of the following is the 
probable site of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
From the history, it is clear that the patient is suffering fron anterograde amnesia, most probably 
due to a lesion is hippocampus. Hippocampus is the primary structure within the temporal lobe involved in conversion of 
short-term memory to long-term memory. Hippocampal cognitive map is inappropriately reactivated during a deja vu experience. Hippocampus does not store memory but only converts short-term memory to long-term memory. 
Hence, hippocampal lesions cause only anterograde amnesia.

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following is correctly paired to show the relationship between a brain area and a 
type of memory?

options.b: Medial temporal lobe and declarative memory

questions.explanation:
348 
Sold by @itachibot Declarative memory involves the hippocampus and the medial temporal lobe for retention. Priming - neocortex. Procedural memory - striatum. Associative learning- amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor 
responses. Nonassociative learning - various reflex pathways.

questions.question:
Question 26: A 35-year-old man is severely injured in a road traffic accident. Brain MRI shows significant 
damage to the bilateral frontal lobes. Which of the following neurological features will be 
least likely seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Retained judgement will be least likely seen if the patient survives such a devastating injury. Injury to the frontal lobe may lead to frontal lobe syndrome, which consists of poor judgment, 
slowed thinking, decreased curiosity, social withdrawal, and irritability. Frontal lobe injury: • Impairs the executive functions: motivation, attention, and sequencing of actions • Aphasia, apraxia, constructional apraxia, neglect, and memory deficits can be seen • Characterized by changes in personality • Apathetic indifference and impulsive behaviour. • Commonly urinary incontinence and faecal incontinence is seen • Commonly produced by trauma, infarcts, tumours, lobotomy, multiple sclerosis, or Pick's 
disease. Frontal lobe pathology may become apparent only under unstructured, stressful, real-life 
situations and are difficult to detect in intelligence scales, as IQ mostly requires parietal lobe 
activation.

questions.question:
Question 27: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is 
likely to be affected?
questions.explanation:
Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus A lesion in this region leads to motor/Broca's aphasia. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted by 
many word-finding pauses. The speech is impoverished in function words that contribute to the 
syntax but is enriched in meaningful nouns and verbs. However, comprehension of speech is 
intact and the patient knows what he wants to say. For example, a patient with Broca's aphasia may say "walk dog" instead of "I want to take the dog 
for a walk".

questions.question: Question 28: What is Prosopagnosia?
questions.explanation:
349 
Sold by @itachibot Prosopagnosia is difficulty in identifying known faces. In humans, storage and recognition of faces is more strongly represented in the right inferior 
temporal lobe in right-handed individuals, though the left lobe is also active. Damage to this area 
can cause prosopagnosia. Patients with this abnormality can recognize forms and reproduce them. They can recognize 
people by their voices, and many of them show autonomic responses when they see familiar as 
opposed to unfamiliar faces. However, they cannot identify the familiar faces they see. The left 
hemisphere is also involved, but the role of the right hemisphere is primary. The presence of autonomic response to a familiar face in the absence of recognition has been 
explained by postulating the existence of a separate dorsal pathway for processing information 
about faces that leads to recognition at only a subconscious level. Note: • Autotopagnosia - inability to recognize or to orient any part of one's own body • Simultagnosia - inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or 
some elements of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole • Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one’s own or another’s body • Tactile agnosia (astereognosis) - inability to recognize objects by touch, in the presence of intact 
cutaneous and proprioceptive hand sensation; caused by a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe

questions.question: Question 29: Emotion is regulated by:

options.c: Secrete variety of molecules that aid in lung defence
options.d: Membrane bound organelles namely lamellar bodies are present

questions.explanation:
Emotion is regulated by the frontal lobe. There are two aspects of emotion: • Genesis of emotion and rating of emotional importance –from the limbic system – amygdala. • The limbic system houses the emotional association areas, which direct the hypothalamus to 
express the motor and endocrine components of the emotional state. • The amygdala rates the emotional importance of an experience and activates the hippocampus 
(memory) accordingly. Thus an emotionally intense experience is etched in memory, which is the 
basis for learned fear responses. • Damage to the amygdala ablates the ability to distinguish fear and anger in other persons' voices 
and facial expressions. • Regulation of emotion - frontal lobe. 350 
Sold by @itachibot The Limbic System Nppocsmpue 351 
Sold by @itachibot Functional Anatomy
